data.title: JsonFormatter / Add JSON Serialization Support

milestone.title: Future
milestone.description: New systems and modules requiring a significant amount of long-term effort.

data.body:
- Add support for [JSON](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JSON) as alternative to XML.
- Pro:
  - Smaller Resource files
  - Higher data frequency than XML, but still human-readable
  - A good excuse to create a [plugin API for adding custom serialization formats](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/issues/94) to Duality
- Con:
  - Need to create said plugin API first in order to keep additional dependencies out of the core
  - Probably won't add that much of value to the user, will still need to be maintained

data.title: Custom materials can become shared at runtime
data.body:
This seems to be a fairly obscure bug, but it's reproducible. I've put some data files and code up here to download to make this quicker to diagnose - https://www.dropbox.com/s/2p5q9hi5a98b2lk/ReproSharedCustomMaterials.zip. Just drop these into any vanilla Duality Game folder and open the scene.

Basically, it looks like any game objects that have SpriteRenderers (or any other renderers) with custom materials that share the same technique and have the same starting shader uniform values, that are inactive when the game starts and become active in the same frame, start sharing the custom material. It doesn't seem to matter whether the components are activated through code or through the editor. Interestingly though, it doesn't seem to happen when the two objects are linked to prefabs. After stopping the sandbox, the two custom materials remain linked!

data.title: Custom material is sometimes shared between game objects
data.body: To reproduce, create two game objects with SpriteRenderer components. Select both game objects, then in the Object Inspector, click the + to create a custom material. Choose a technique that exposes some shader variables. Deselect the game objects and reselect just one. Now, set one of the shader variables in the Object Inspector. The same value will also be set for the other game object.

data.title: Guarantee CorePlugin.InitPlugin consistency during reload
data.body:
- As stated [here](http://forum.fetzenet.de/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=242), it may be possible for InitPlugin to be called before all plugins are present, if multiple plugins are reloaded simultaneously.
- Investigate and debug, when necessary.

data.title: Improve CorePlugin API
data.body:
- As stated [here](http://forum.fetzenet.de/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=242), there are situations where it is necessary to perform a plugin initialization step after all other plugins have been initialized.
- Rename CorePlugin.InitPlugin to LoadPlugin, and introduce new InitPlugin method, which is called after all other plugins have been loaded. Essentially the same setup as present in EditorPlugins.

data.title: ContentProvider.GetAvailableContent shouldn't load Resources
data.body: As described [here](http://forum.fetzenet.de/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=242), said method appears to cause loading Resources. This should not be the case. Verify and debug when necessary.

data.title: Use nuget for dependency management
data.body:
I see a lot of the last few comits are related to dependencies, I mentioned this before in the forums but I think I has become a bigger issue.

Some dependencies that are now in submodules , some committed (nunit) It seems to me that it would be better if they were managed consistently, and given the current state of .net, I think managing dependencies with nuget is the way to go .

I don't know what has been your experience with submodules, but most of mine have been rather painful, they can be tricky to manage. At the same time, it seems to me that there is no reason to use this method when what you need is a solution to manage binaries

If you are concerned about the central nuget repository there are options : you can create a local cache, and also you can have your assemblies on your own server (if that is something you want), and also you can use myget (free for open feeds)

Benefits:
- no more dlls committed to source control, so no guess work on the version of the dll you are using
- you can check what version you are using from source control (by checking packages.config)
- no need for visual studio for building the solutions, just msbuild 
- if you don't have the dependecies nuget can go and fetch for you (you need to enable this in the solution)

I can implement this however it would be great if I know it will be merged

data.title: Long-Term Switch to WPF?
data.body:
- Evaluate whether or not it is necessary or useful to switch from WinForms to WPF in the long run.
  - Is it necessary? Will WinForms support be dropped sooner or later?
  - Is it useful? Will usability benefit?
- Evaluate how much work it would be to move, without removing or reducing any functional or usability features.
  - Porting AdamsLair.WinForms to WPF
  - Finding an alternative to WeifenLuo.Docking
  - Finding an alternative to TreeViewAdv
- See whether or not the benefits outweigh the drawbacks.

data.title: Snap-To-Grid in CamView module
data.body:
- An optional, customizable snap-to-grid functionality would be very nice.
- A dropdown menu in the CamView toolbar should do the job.
  - Inside it, there are N checkable entries for grid presets (32x32, 64x64, ...)
  - An one checkable entry "Custom: AxB" that will open up a config dialog or contains numeric editor sub-entries,

data.title: Allow External EditorHintImages
data.body:
- In the current implementation of EditorHintImage, all images are forced to be included within the CorePlugin, even though the editor might not be shipped with the game.
- This may not be wanted in all cases. There should be a way to externalize these images and make their existence optional (despite their declaration), so they can be easily stripped from the release version.
- A possible solution would be to fall back on searching EditorPlugins for a matching embedded Resource class, in case the CorePlugin doesn't have one. If nothing is found at all, this shouldn't cause an error, since it may be entirely possible that the release version of a game does not contain any icon information.

data.title: Remove Serialization MetaFormat
data.body:
- The serialization MetaFormat clutters the codebase and significantly increases the implementation of existing and new Formatter classes, as it essentially requires all of them to have a similar structure.
- To remove it would decrease overall framework complexity, which is a good thing in this case.
## Impact and Issues
1. XmlMetaFormatter and BinaryMetaFormatter will be removed.
2. XmlFormatter can be merged with XmlFormatterBase, and the same goes for BinaryFormatter and BinaryFormatterBase. A lot of their complexity will vanish.
3. The editor will now longer be able to rely on the MetaFormat to rename Types and Namespaces when creating a new project.
4. The ResourceHacker module becomes obsolete and will be removed as well. It will no longer be possible to use it for bulk renaming, etc.
5. Different Formatters will be allowed to utilize different data structures that fit better to their kind.
## Solutions and Thoughts
1. Improvement
2. Improvement
3. This is a technical issue that needs to be dealt with. It is not possible to use temporary SerializeTypeHandlers for this purpose - because this will require the new Types to be resolvable, which isn't the case. There will be the need for some other solution.
   - String Operations on Xml Format?
   - New kind of operation for Formatter classes that reads from one stream, performs an operation on unresolved data, and directly writes it to a different stream? 
   - Or maybe the same with two Formatters, so each one still only operates on one stream.
   - Or let that operation perform on a single stream with both reading and writing, so each Formatter class can handle it on its own. XmlFormatters could just find/replace on the document, BinaryFormatters could use the boundary markers to read and modify only headers, while writing other memory unchanged.
   - Or something else. No final solution yet.
4. Using a human-readable data format will serve the same purpose and be a lot more efficient and easy at the same time. So this will not be a problem.
5. Improvement

data.title: PropertyGrid should reflect on actual value
data.body:
- The PropertyGrid is unable to handle expanding Members of Type `object` or `ISomeTestInterface`, because it only reflects on the Member Type, but not the Type of the actual value.
- This should be implemented. Wherever possible, the actual value Type should be preferred for providing sub editors.
- The Member Type can be used as a fallback.
- Affects: MemberwisePropertyEditor, IListPropertyEditor, IDictionaryPropertyEditor.

data.title: User Dialog for Serialize Error Handling in the Editor

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
- Define a lowest-priority (!) SerializeErrorHandler in the editor, which creates a popup dialog that lets the user react to the error. For example by specifying the new name of a renamed class, or explicitly resolving references to deleted classes with null.
- Dialog choices should be remembered and auto-applied in the future. 
  - Don't save them, though - they are not to be considered a permanent replacement for manually provided error handlers.
- Tell the user how to handle those errors directly via code and probably offer auto-generating such handler classes based on his.

data.title: Publish button
data.body:
I was thinking that a publish button would be a nice feature to have. 

The basic purpose of the button is to create a bundle (zip/folder) that contains only the _core_ needed files to deploy the game to someone.With an additional checkbox maybe? for including the "debug" things? 
I was thinking just looking at the Wiki list of needed files under the 2 sections and creating 2 publish modes that would create the required bundle based on those defaults?

data.title: Visual Debug Output / Logging
data.body:
- Implement some kind of visual debugging functionality.
- `Duality.Components.Diagnostics.VisualDebugLog` Component will cache and render stuff.
- `Duality.Components.Diagnostics` will hold all the visual debugging helper classes
- Provides publicly accessible debug draw API
  - Call from anywhere, at any time, submit when rendering.
  - Easy-access and fast-to-write are top priorities.
  - Even complex operations shouldn't require more than 2-3 lines, ideally only one.
  - There should be a global way to quickly access the VisualDebugLog, similar to `Log.Core`, `Log.Editor` and `Log.Game`.
    - Static Properties? 
    - Static Method for retrieving a certain custom log?
    - Auto-Create, if non-existent?
- Allow rendering in:
  - Screen Space
  - World Space
  - Object Space (of any object)
- Allow rendering of:
  - Well-defined set of visual debug data.
    - Don't let the user specify _how_ to draw something, let him specify _what_ to display and let the system decide. Pro: "Free graphics update" for the user debug stuff when the rendering code gets improved.
    - Points `A`
    - Vectors `A->`
    - Connections `A-B`, optional with thickness
    - Circle Areas `(-----A--r--)`, optional with angles and inner radius
    - Polygonal Areas (Convex)
    - Text
  - Persistent: Call once, draw for X seconds
  - Per-Frame: Call once, render once
- How to implement?
  - Internally store data to display, with anchor, lifetime, etc.
  - Render everything

data.title: Clean up Editor Codebase
data.body:
- While Duality's core is in quite a good shape, the editor code isn't so easy to get into.
- it's too hard to write EditorPlugins :(
- `EditorBase` is a bad example, since all the base modules, formats, etc. are crammed into one plugin.
- `IPropertyEditorProvider` does a bad job and feels unnecessary.
- `CorePluginRegistry` feels unnecessary, too: "Why do I need to register everything explicitly? I don't need to do so in a CorePlugin..."
- Why are Type images and Type categories in an EditorPlugin, although EditorHints allow specifying metadata within a CorePlugin?
- Why is there a separate `DualityEditor` namespace when `Duality.Editor` would be more appropriate? Also, EditorHints could go there as well.
## Proposed Changes
- **Done:** Split `EditorBase` into multiple separate EditorPlugins.
  - Probably one per module.
- **Done:** Rename `DualityEditor` namespace to `Duality.Editor` 
  - Also, move EditorHints there.
  - Plugin namespaces will be `Duality.Editor.Plugins.XY`
- **Done:** Get rid of `IPropertyEditorProviders`, use Reflection instead.
  - Introduce [PropretyEditorAssignment] attribute
  - Can be used as a class attribute on classes deriving from PropertyEditor in order to link that editor to a specific Type (and its derivatives) to edit.
  - Can be used as a static method attribute on classes deriving from PropertyEditor in order to provide an assignment function that determines the level of Type association for that editor based on certain parameters.
- **Done:** Get rid of `RegisterTypeCategory` and `RegisterTypeImage` 
  - Use newly introduced EditorHints instead.
- **Done:** If possible, get rid of `CorePluginRegistry` alltogether.
  - With PropertyEditors, TypeImages and TypeCategories gone, what's left is as follows:
  - **Done:** `EditorActions`: Could probably transform EditorActions to attributes, which can be assigned to static methods. Right now, that's what they are doing anyway.
  - **Done:** `DataConverter`; Could be replaced by using class attributes on DataConverters, assigning each one a target Type.
  - **Done:** `PreviewGenerator`: Don't even need an attribute. Just use all non-abstract classes implementing  IPreviewGenerator.
  - **Done:** `FileImporter`: Dont' need an attribute here either. Again, just use Reflection.
  - **Done:** `XmlCodeDoc`: Move to HelpSystem.
  - **Done:** `DesignTimeData`: Move to `DualityEditorApp` or new helper class.

data.title: GraphicsContextMissingException in RenderTarget on editor restart
data.body:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a scene that uses a RenderTarget resource in some way.
2. Modify plugin code and rebuild in such a way as to force a complete editor restart.
3. After restart, RenderTarget.MaxRenderTargetSamples throws GraphicsContextMissingException with the message "No context is current in the calling thread"

It looks like either the Scene has been reloaded before OpenGL has been fully initialized, or this code is running on a different thread, presumably the UI thread? Stack trace below.

OpenTK.dll!OpenTK.Graphics.OpenGL.ErrorHelper.ErrorHelper(OpenTK.Graphics.IGraphicsContext context) Unknown

data.title: Deep(er) Evaluation for Collections in PrefabLink Changelists
data.body:
- It would be neat if one could overwrite just one element value of a list within a Prefab.
- See [here](http://www.fetzenet.de/forum/viewtopic.php?f=4&t=189)

data.title: Avoid Newbie Pitfalls
data.body:
**Update: Done!**
- The first Scene that is saved should be implicitly assigned to the StartScene setting.
- The first Scene after creating a new project should contain a Camera / AudioListener object.
- When hitting the "Start Game" button without a value assigned to StartScene, assign the Scene that is currently opened, provided it exists as a Resource. If not, use one of them. If there are none, and the current Scene isn't empty, save it and use that one.

data.title: Public Variables not showing up in object inspector
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a new project
2. Create a new gameobject
3. Open Source code editor
4. Edit "YourCustomComponentType.cs" and add a public variable of some kind and build the code
5. Add "YourCustomComponentType" to a gameobject
6. Note how you are unable to see the public variable you created in the Object Inspector
7. Click the "Debug Mode" button at the top of the Object Inspector
8. Note how you can now see your variable, even though it is public (and Debug Mode says "Show _non-public_ members"

Core Version: 1.0.5127.30990
Editor Version: 1.0.5127.30991

data.title: Can't modify game object Component collection during collision events
data.body: Modifying the components collection of a game object from inside an OnCollision... method results in an InvalidOperationException from NotifyCollisionBegin because it's currently iterating through the components collection.
